sections.heading: Reason for Referral
sections.content: Ms. Jane Doe is being referred to Rheumatology for further evaluation of persistent joint pain and swelling that has not responded to initial conservative management.

sections.heading: History of Present Illness
sections.content: The patient reports a six-month history of intermittent pain and swelling affecting the small joints of her hands and wrists, particularly in the morning. She describes morning stiffness lasting over an hour and recent difficulty performing tasks that require fine motor skills. There is no significant history of trauma, recent infections, or family history of autoimmune disease. Over-the-counter analgesics have provided minimal relief.

sections.heading: Assessment
sections.content: On examination, there is notable synovitis of the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints bilaterally. Laboratory results show mild elevation of ESR and CRP, with negative rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP antibodies. X-rays of the hands show no erosive changes. The findings are suggestive of an early inflammatory arthropathy, possibly seronegative rheumatoid arthritis.

sections.heading: Plan
sections.content: Referral to Rheumatology for further diagnostic workup and consideration of disease-modifying therapy. Recommend continued use of NSAIDs for symptom control and initiation of hand physiotherapy. The patient has been advised to monitor for any new symptoms and return for follow-up as needed.
